awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  The Development of Biodegradable Hot Melt Pressure Sensitive Adhesives for Use in Hygiene Products
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is in development of fully-biodegradable disposable personal care products, particularly menstrual pads. In general, menstrual pads cannot be recycled or be composted by municipal facilities after use because of issues with the biodegradable hot-melt adhesives to construct and position them. Biodegradation may be the best way to reduce the environmental impact associated with them, particularly in geographies where municipal solid waste facilities are underdeveloped.  Ultimately, non-toxic, safe and effective disposable menstrual pads could improve quality of life for menstruating women and the environment, and provide a new commercial opportunity for producers in the US and around the globe.

The proposed project addresses the technical challenge of synthesizing a combination of biodegradable thermoplastics and biological additives that will create a pressure sensitive adhesive (PSA). This PSA must performs well in commercial hot glue application machinery as well as in the intended products, completely and safely degrade within six months of use, and is commercially viable at scale. These parameters have yet to be met by biological-based adhesives. The research approach is as follows: First, develop and synthesize PSAs using a biological base polymer and biological-based biodegradable additives, including plasticizers, tackifiers, and compatibilizers to enhance the performance of the PSAs. Second, characterize PSAs based on established use and manufacturing requirements and optimize the composition to ensure the requirements are met. Third, test PSA compositions for degradation, including length of time required for complete biodegradation under landfill, soil, and water conditions, including marine environments.  Identify intermediate chemical molecules and structures that form as a result of the biodegradation process, determine their potential hazards on both the environment and the health of biological organisms.  This project will develop a biodegradable PSA that will meet manufacturing and performance standards in menstrual pads and show that the PSA can be fully biodegradable in less than six months under non-specialized environmental conditions, without the need of mechanochemical or photo degradation processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the NSF-funded SBIR project, ?The Development of Biodegradable Pressure Sensitive Hot Melt Adhesives for Use in Hygiene Products,? is to develop a biodegradable adhesive that can be used on existing high-speed menstrual pad manufacturing equipment and meets the performance requirements of menstrual pad users, as measured by peel strength. 

In Phase I of this project, pressure sensitive adhesives were developed using a biodegradable base polymer and biodegradable additives. The viscosity and peel strengths of these adhesives were thoroughly and systematically evaluated. The results of this analysis can be simply summarized as: the ingredients that increase the adhesive strength also decrease the viscosity. Two formulations that balanced these two properties were tested at a pilot scale manufacturing trial with an adhesives manufacturer. These adhesives proved compatible with existing, high-speed manufacturing equipment, as measured by their viscosity at processing temperatures between 130-150C, but measured lower peel strength than desired. To address this, an elastomer (a rubbery polymer) was added to the better of these adhesive formulations. This modified adhesive has a peel strength comparable to current industry adhesives while maintaining a similar viscosity. 

To test the third criteria for these samples, biodegradability, the sample adhesives were tested in water, soil and compost. Twenty-eight-day tests of the elastomer-modified adhesive samples showed limited biodegradation in freshwater. After seven months in soil, the samples are biodegrading, albeit slowly. Finally, in the most biologically-active environment?compost--the samples disintegrated in 8 weeks and showed positive chemical changes suggesting biodegration.

Subsequent research plans involve making novel and proprietary modifications to the polymer backbone of the elastomer used in this adhesive to enable adhesives made with this modified elastomer to meet the three critical development criteria: appropriate viscosity, appropriate peel strength, and biodegradation in a variety of disposal scenarios.   

There is a need for menstrual products that are clean and safe and also have a decreased end-of-life burden. Used menstrual products are not candidates for recycling or most composting facilities, and when not properly disposed, are among those plastic-based products most likely to escape into waterways and oceans. Moreover, the ability to manage one?s menstruation with dignity is a human right, according to the United Nations. Hence the size of the disposal problem is likely to grow as access to menstrual products increases, particularly in developing areas. With the exception of biodegradable hot melt adhesives, all other components required to make biodegradable menstrual pads are currently commercially available. The lack of an appropriate hot melt adhesive is a technical hurdle to biodegradable pads. Building on the knowledge developed through this effort, and modifying the polymer backbone of the adhesive elastomer to enable biodegradation, could lead to the commercialization of a biodegradable hot melt adhesive and catalyze the menstrual pad industry to manufacture biodegradable pads widely and at scale, thus meeting an important societal need with an environmentally-friendly and sustainable product.
